title: (Cross-post from Reddit) "Day in the Life"-type questions for Riot software devs
body:
I'm a software engineer who graduated a couple years ago and I'm super interested in applying to work for Riot at some point in the next couple of years. I've read most of the stuff you guys have online, including the "Day in the Life" article about the software dev from Hong Kong, the Riot dev blog, and the various open job descriptions. I have a few more questions, though:

(A. Intro, how long have you worked there? What does your team do? What technologies do you work with?)

1. How often do you actually play League during work hours?
2. What's the coding culture like? Does it "feel" like a big company where you're a just a cog and there's lots of red tape, or does it feel smaller where you have more freedom but also more responsibility? Or maybe it's a mix?
3. How free are you to experiment with new technologies?
4. How often do you find yourself working evenings/weekends, and how much of that could you avoid if you didn't want to? Are you on-call and is it required for most dev teams to be on-call?
5. What are some of the more important non-technical aspects of a new hire that you look for in interviews & resume reviews? (If you do that sort of thing)
6. What are some nice things about being a dev at Riot Games, and if you feel comfortable, what are some not-so-nice things you'd change if you could?

Thanks in advance! You guys rock, the game rocks, don't let toxic Boards-ers keep you down, and keep up the good work!

Edit: My post was removed from the subreddit because it addressed only Rioters instead of all LoL players. But I can't figure out how to remove the link, so we're going to go ahead and ignore it!
